content: "http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0509/22568.html" quote: Al Gore said Friday that fellow former Vice President Dick Cheney has jumped back into the political fray too soon into the new administration’s term. “I waited two years after I left office to make statements that were critical,” Gore said during an interview on CNN, pointing out that his critiques were focused on “policy". Guess this is a case of another Democrat with selective memory. quote: Boston Globe, 4/14/2002: "'They are wrong to vilify honorable men and women who oppose their right-wing domestic agenda and oppose a blatantly dishonest budget,' Gore said. 'They are wrong to imply that those who stand up to them are somehow unpatriotic.'" (Headline -- "Combative Gore Lashes Out At Administration Policies In Fla. Speech, He Hits Bush For 'Radical Agenda'") [Note: So much for his assertion today that his early criticsm of the Bush Administration focused on policy.] USA Today, 4/15/2002: "Gore's speech was the emotional peak of the convention. With practiced skill, humor and a passion some delegates said they did not see during the campaign, Gore denounced virtually every element of Bush's domestic policy." (Headline -- "Gore's fiery speech raises questions of plans") NY Times, 4/23/2002: "Sounding very much like the candidate he was and may become again, Al Gore said today that the environment was a moral issue and the Bush administration was giving 'policy payoffs to polluters.' 'Our environment is under siege,' Mr. Gore , the former vice president, said in an Earth Day speech here to 400 students at Vanderbilt University. 'The Bush administration has chosen to serve the special interests instead of the public interests and subsidize the obsolete failed approaches of the past instead of the exciting new solutions of the future. Instead of ensuring that our water is clean to drink, they thought that maybe there wasn't enough arsenic in the drinking water.'" LA Times, 6/30/2002: "In a speech Saturday night to local Democrats, Gore attacked Bush's economic policies as "a total catastrophe." He also noted that in the war on terrorism, the U.S. has yet to catch Al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden, and he denounced the White House for "trying to use the war for political purposes.'" [I guess that's just more pure criticsm of policy ... .] "http://www.weeklystandard.com/weblogs/TWSFP/2009/05/al_gore_hypocritically_attacks.asp" Maybe he learned his note taking skills from Speaker Pelosi or maybe all of the CO2 we release into the atmosphere is rotting his brain.

content: Knowing how the love of the Constitution plays on the well being of ultra-rightous, try this on for size. Article II Section 1. The executive power shall be vested in a President of the United States of America. He shall hold his office during the term of four years, and, together with the Vice President, chosen for the same term, be elected, as follows: Didn't say eight years, says four. Both Cheney and Gore overstayed their welcome.

content: quote: Originally posted by rayevinsonsr: Knowing how the love of the Constitution plays on the well being of ultra-rightous, try this on for size. Article II Section 1. The executive power shall be vested in a President of the United States of America. He shall hold his office during the term of four years, and, together with the Vice President, chosen for the same term, be elected, as follows: Didn't say eight years, says four. Both Cheney and Gore overstayed their welcome. Didn't say that a President is limited to four years. The pendant in me kicks in. As far as the orginal Constitution goes, you can be elected until you drop dead of old age. The change came in 1952 with the 22nd Amendment. And I personally have little use for term limits. But Ray, didn't you read the 47 Amendment? It shows that Gore was right... Dave

content: Just playing with words Fish. The document says he shall serve one term, 4 years, until the 22nd Amendment limiting two terms. Thank FDR. Mr. Washington didn't care for the second term added to him but reluctant set a precedent until Roosevelt broke the unwritten rule. Yes Dave I read all 47 of your amendments. The 27 acknowledged by the Congress and States and the twenty only known to you. I agree, Gore was right on keeping quite, but needs work on torture and weather reports. (The Bill of Rights original was more than ten than were accepted. Some failed to see the reason for any)

But Ray, didn't you read the 47 Amendment? It shows that Gore was right... Dave
quote: Originally posted by rayevinsonsr: Knowing how the love of the Constitution plays on the well being of ultra-rightous, try this on for size. Article II Section 1. The executive power shall be vested in a President of the United States of America. He shall hold his office during the term of four years, and, together with the Vice President, chosen for the same term, be elected, as follows: Didn't say eight years, says four. Both Cheney and Gore overstayed their welcome.
reply: Didn't say that a President is limited to four years. The pendant in me kicks in. As far as the orginal Constitution goes, you can be elected until you drop dead of old age. The change came in 1952 with the 22nd Amendment. And I personally have little use for term limits. But Ray, didn't you read the 47 Amendment? It shows that Gore was right... Dave

content: Just playing with words Fish. The document says he shall serve one term, 4 years, until the 22nd Amendment limiting two terms. Thank FDR. Mr. Washington didn't care for the second term added to him but reluctant set a precedent until Roosevelt broke the unwritten rule. Yes Dave I read all 47 of your amendments. The 27 acknowledged by the Congress and States and the twenty only known to you. I agree, Gore was right on keeping quite, but needs work on torture and weather reports. (The Bill of Rights original was more than ten than were accepted. Some failed to see the reason for any)

content: quote: Grant and one other President wanted to run for a third term. Grant and Roosevelt and Roosevelt. Teddy as well, but in his case he hated the Republican ultra rich ruining his party. People talk about neo-cons. It was old and new at the turn of the turn of the 20th century. The GM motor cars, Goodyear tires, Standard oil were buying out the competition and the future of our country. The anti-trust of the 70's replaced by deregulation of the 106th Congress 1998, so the sympathy of the demise of big business today is strictly for the employee's.

content: I don't think Cheney actually wants to be out speaking. I think it is more like poking a sleeping bear. When the Obama admi starting releasing selective photo's or info with regard to torture when the libs are calling for war crimes, I think it forced his hand to come out and make a case. If you think about it, he was never a big fan of talking to the press or explaining anything the Bush admin was doing. They certainly never defended anything they were doing which came back to bite them in the behind in the end.
